@graph.involvedParties: Pacific Bell Telephone Co., dba AT&T California, et al. v. Linkline Communications, Inc., et al.
@graph.reasoning: Petitioners (hereinafter AT&T) own infrastructure and facilities needed to provide “DSL” service, a method of connecting to the Internet at high speeds over telephone lines.

@graph.involvedParties: Verizon Communications Inc. v. Law Offices of Curtis V. Trinko, LLP
@graph.reasoning: A firm with no antitrust duty to deal with its rivals has no obligation to provide those rivals with a “sufficient” level of service.

@graph.involvedParties: Brooke Group Ltd. v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp.
@graph.reasoning: Established two requirements for predatory pricing: below-cost retail pricing and a “dangerous probability” that the defendant will recoup any lost profits.
Businesses are generally free to choose the parties with whom they will deal, as well as the prices, terms, and conditions of that dealing.

@graph.involvedParties: Aspen Skiing Co. v. Aspen Highlands Skiing Corp.
@graph.reasoning: Limited circumstances in which a firm’s unilateral refusal to deal with its rivals can give rise to antitrust liability.

@graph.involvedParties: Matsushita Elec. Industrial Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp.
@graph.reasoning: Cutting prices in order to increase business often is the very essence of competition.
Pleading standard articulated in Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U. S. 544, 561–563
